description:
Crissy Field is one of the grand stages for The Blue Angels F/A-18 Hornet Supersonic Jets air show during Fleet Week in San Francisco in October when they zoom through the skies coming through the Golden Gate Bridge crossing the bay along Crissy Field in no more than a few seconds, and onwards between downtown highrise office buildings. Working in the downtown area during their death defying practice runs, I can honestly say they get so close to the buildings that you can almost touch them as they literally scream through. You actually hear them before you see them, having a top speed of over mach 1.7. Crissy Field is a perfect place to see these amazing supersonic jets, it offers "enough" parking during this event, but you still have to arrive early to stake your space as they fill up fast as it gets closer to show time. The venue is also large enough to allow everyone a good view of the jets as they perform their death defying acrobatics at speeds close to the speed of sound, and if you're lucky, they may even entertain you with a vapor cone at transonic speed just before booming through the speed of sound. Literally with a loud audible boom! If you want to view The Blue Angels air show in San Francisco during Fleet Week from Crissy field, plan on getting out there around 11:30am to stake a comfortable claim on the field, spread out your towels, food, drinks, and assorted toys like a football or baseball or frisbee to keep you busy. Lay down, enjoy a nap, enjoy a book, enjoy the company of your friends and family, and enjoy the unmatched San Francisco views while you wait for the air show to begin. A number of other airplanes like the Team Oracle biplane and The Patriots Jet Team participating in the show will start to fly around 12:30pm. Just before the Blue Angels start to fly, you may be entertained by a United Airlines Boeing 747 flying so low to the Golden Gate Bridge you might even get an urge to call Homeland Security. But rest assured, it's part of the show, at least for the many years I've attended. And just moments before the Blue Angels start to appear from the Sausalito and Tiburon skies, the Navy Aircraft C-130 affectionately known as "Fat Albert" will put on a dazzling show of acrobatics, flying at a 90 degree angle straight up towards the sky which is no small feat considering the husky build of the plane. My family and I have enjoyed watching the Blue Angels since my son was 2 years old, minus year 2013 when the Blue Angels were absent, my son is now 13 years old and the show is still one of the big events he looks forward to every year.

http://studio-v.wingsdomain.com/featured/blue-angels-f-18-super-hornet-7d8129-wingsdomain-art-and-photography.html

http://studio-v.wingsdomain.com/featured/blue-angels-f-18-super-hornet-7d7948-wingsdomain-art-and-photography.html
author: Wingsdomain.com V.

description:
Glad to live in one of the few places in the world where seeing military jets don't make me fear for my life.   Watched last year from top of City Hall dome and was pretty cool.   They buzz the dome as a marker I think. 

Definitely a good reminder how fast we can wipe out things we disagree with.
author: Larry W.

description: The best air show with the backdrop of one of the greatest and coolest city in the world. What more to say about it? Simply stunning!
author: Gopi V.

description:
What an amazing show! 

Beautiful venue to begin with. It was a sunny Saturday after lunch time in October 2016. We walked all the way from Embarcadero to watch the show and it was spectacular! A lot of people had gathered to watch the show from different spots. We climbed a bit high up to be able to catch the blue angels dancing around the Alcatraz. Got some good shots too.

Can't wait for the show this year and i'm definitely bringing my camera again :)

Amazing coordination from the pilots! Beautiful event. Highly recommend!
author: Heliana M.

description: The Blue Angels always put on a good show when they come to the Bay Area.  Plenty of great viewing spots all over the Bay as they cover the whole area.  Even the weekdays before the show, you can see them practicing all week long.  Their show is free (obviously) and although SF is crowded, you don't necessarily have to go there to see them, although the best viewing spots are in the city.
author: Phil A.

description:
Date: 10/9/2016  Time: 2:15 PM  71°  Sunny

This is my first time actually being in San Francisco for Fleet Week to watch the Blue Angels. 

My husband and I caught the ferry from Alameda to San Francisco for this event. Our perch site was the upper platform of the Sausalito Ferry Terminal. We chose this site for viewing, figuring Pier 41 and the Fisherman's Wharf/Pier 39 would be very crowded. We even sat in the shade and we were comfortable...very comfortable.

Sitting and/or standing, we were able to catch some of the spectacular maneuvers of the Blue Angels, roaring by at a very rapid pace. It was an awesome sight and there were plenty of oohs and aahs from the spectators around us. Sometimes I lost track of them in the bright sunlight. However, I still enjoyed and appreciated what I have seen - the precision of these jet pilots performing the amazing feats on a beautiful day.

We will return to the same site with our folding chairs to watch the Blue Angels next year, which is the upper platform of the Sausalito Ferry Terminal. The view there is great, and it is also convenient for us to be close to the ferry terminal to take us back to Alameda/Oakland.
author: Carol C.

description: The Blue Angels put on the the best outdoor show in the world.  Every year the come to Seattle for our SeaFair event and entertain the city.  Looking forward to them coming back to town again this summer!
author: John H.

description: So much excitement when they are here, especially when they take off and land ...gibes me goosebumps. I usually watch from crissy field and I feel it's a great spot unless you can watch from some tall building facing the bay bridge. Amazing show as always.
author: Pritika M.

description:
I go to see the Blue Angels show every year. My kids (4 to 10 year olds) love it and each time they want to come with me.

It is often difficult to find good parking and there are in general too many people on this day.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
VMOOOOOOOOOOOOOM!!

Without the Blue Angels, there would be no Fleet Week....

What a beautiful sunny San Francisco day. My gf's and I decided to view it first hand at the Crissy Fields, on the Marina.

No other word to describe just..... SPECTACULAR!
author: Janet T.

description: After seeing the Blue Angels perform in real life at Fleet Week, I was definitely impressed by their extremely precise formations and high speed aerial maneuvers. I viewed the Blue Angels on the ground at Pier 39 and on the cruise ship on two different days. Viewing the Blue Angels on the ground at Pier 39 was actually more enjoyable than viewing on a top deck in a cruise ship since they managed to make the effort to fly over large crowds of spectators compared to the much smaller spectators on the cruise ship. I thought the jets weren't loud enough because they were just flying too fast and high! I love the roar of the F-18!
author: David L.

description:
Blue Angels are always a great opportunity to see how few can break the barrier of the sound. The speed and strategies , acrobatic moves are amazing.
The only thing that I didn't like is how it ended.... it was sandenly done.
author: Carla D.

description: Freaking awesome!!!!! F18s flying over the bay, tons of people out and about, the city showing its beauty to millions. What a great experience.
author: J W.

description:
STOP wasting gas on your military propoganda.
And stop buzzing our households. I'm sick of my house shaking as you fly by.
author: Kyra T.

description:
All I did was type terror in the search bar
I was presented this and I don't care for it
author: George M.

description:
It was my first time watching the Blue Angels ever and I was super excited to be a speculator in the Marina. I've heard some pretty awesome things from it and I was disappointed!

They performed some very intriguing maneuvers that left people gasping followed by a round of applause. The first thirty minutes captured my attention but later on they kept doing the same things so it got kind of boring.

10 minutes before it ended, my friend and I decided to leave before everyone starts leaving.

I'd definitely watch them again!
author: Aj C.

description: Need I say more about the Blue Angels air show during the annual Fleet Week in San Francisco Bay? Instead of watching from the Fisherman's Wharf or Marina Green this year, I went to the Alcatraz, though. There I got great photo shots of the show with the city skyline in the background as well as Golden Gate Bridge and Bay Bridge. It's a little farther than watching from Fisherman's Wharf , so do bring your binocular or camera with wide angel or telephoto lens if you want to see more clearly from Alcatraz. I would also check the show schedule on line in advance so that I know the exact time and team to fly.
author: Claire W.

description:
Before you can see them zoom through the air, you hear the roar of the fearless Blue Angels booming through the city.  Best seat in town is any rooftop with a view of the Marina Green and Bay.  As they flew past me, I felt very excited to be able to see the Blue Angels in action. The weather was incredible, blue skies for the blue angels. 

Watch them do their routines; the Fat Albert, Diamond Take Off, Opposing Knife Edge Pass, Delta Formation, Barrel rolls and Tuck under rolls. When they fly in formation, their wings touch and you have to realize that these guys know what they are doing and timing is everything.

I watched the whole thing from the roof deck of an apartment building off Chestnut. As I stood there watching them zoom overhead, I felt so fortunate to be right in the middle of the show. I tried to take pictures, but those guys were so fast... I got more pictures of blue skies than Blue Angels.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
VMOOOOOOOOOOOOM!!!!!!!!!!!!

Without the Blue Angels, there would be no Fleet Week. Therefore I love the Blue Angels. 

My girlfriends & I took Uber today to the beautiful Marina Green on this gorgeous day! Blue skies....for the Blue Angels.

Tons of people everywhere but it feels so patriotic.   Its just so American.

They put on an amazing spectacle! Almost made me want to go home and watch 'Top Gun'. HOWEVER......

We all went back to my house to watch MadBum alienate the Cards for Game 1. YES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Janet T.

description: I think I enjoyed, or let me say appreciated, this year the most. We Barted over to Embarcadero from the East Bay and caught a carriage ride most of the way to the Marina Green. It was our 4-year olds 1st time on Bart and 1st time seeing an aerial show. With our faithful BOB stroller, we took a leisurely trek through the crowd of sky stalkers. As I told our Albany park parent buds in the morning...you just have to pretend you are going to Disney World. Expect a big crowd, pain in the butt parking and just enjoy the best parts of the experience. The journey there is all part of it. On our way we hit the $5 bacon wrapped hotdog & $2 ice cream vendors. On our leisurely stroll back, we had dinner at the Cod Mother Fish & Chips.
author: Evelyn K.

description:
Best pilots in the world!!!  How can the Blue Angels not be the biggest draw of Fleet Week? They are amazing to watch. I've seen them when they practice, and I've seen them when they perform. Never to disapoint!!!
They fly so close to each other, one of the best places I was at to watch them was Pier 39, I also got some fabulous pictures that day, photography is a hobby of mine.
One time when I was at Fleet Week the Blue Angels where scheduled to come out, and for some reason they didn't, later I found out that the Blue Angels will not fly if the weather isn't clear. The Blue Angels always put on an excellent show. Should I borrow a line from Top Gun? 'I feel the need the need for a speed.'
author: Peter J.

description:
B-WAH-HA-hahahaha!

Y'alls reviews have me rolling. First there are the, YOU, SIR, ARE NOT A PATRIOT reviews. Here's a tip: These guys are demonstration pilots. They do not do anything in the war on terror. They fly their planes around in formations and do fancy tricks. They waste tax payer money so that you can all stand on the ground with your mouths open and watch and feel all like 'MMERICA! In 'MMERICA we have something called free speech and that means that the hippie folk in San Francisco can whine and complain about war and wasted tax dollars and the noise and you can be all 'MMERICA!

I'm okay with it, are you?

Then there are the THE BLUE ANGELS ARE LOUD AND ARE WAR MONGERERS reviews. Here's a tip: These guys are demonstration pilots. They do not do anything in the war on terror. They fly their planes around in formations and do fancy tricks. They waste tax payer money so that people can all stand on the ground with their mouths open and watch. Free speech means that 'MMERICAN'S are allowed to love this display of military precision once a year and you are allowed to be angry about wasted tax dollars.

 I'm okay with that, are you?
author: Tara H.

description: I hate, no I really hate this.  I wish this could be on the ballot, so those of us who live here could have a say as to whether or not it's "cool" to have the military terrorize residents of an otherwise peaceful city.  Also, what's with Yelp?  I see the majority of negative reviews are either "not recommended" or removed.
author: Lynne A.

description:
True, they may make me jump out of my seat at work when I hear them ZOOM by... and trust me.. it's LOUD!  But you know what, they have a special place in my heart.

As I have mentioned in my review for Fleet Week, my parents used to always take me to Crissy Fields to watch the Blue Angels soar above our heads.  I love the thundering sounds they make!  They zoom!  They spiral!  They twist and turn until you just can't take it anymore!!!  It's just so exhilarating!!  The stunts are also extremely dangerous and pilots have died in the past due to miscalculations, so they have to coordinate everything to the T.  

I highly recommend you check out their show during Fleet Week!  Don't be a Debbie Downer and complain that it's a waste of our government's money, and it causes air pollution, and blah blah blah......   Take a chill pill!  They are coming, and you know it.  It's just disheartening that the military has such a bad relationship with San Franciscans... 

For those who do support them, please check it out!  I'm sure you'll have fun :)
author: Cecilia S.

description:
Oh the Blue Angels! I grew up hearing and seeing them. I once met the pilots (awhile ago when in grade school) and got their autographs! Their one home base / HQ is in FL. The Blue Angels represent the United States Navy and Marine Corps. Their magnificent flight demonstrations have brought ohh's and ahh's to the faces of countless spectators across this country. 

Some minor cons re: their shows (for some - not me)... Loud noise (if you're trying to work), hot weather / possible neck pain when you're trying to view their outdoor / aerial soaring. 

Re: the noise - I say get over it as the Blue Angels aren't flying over this area everyday. Re: weather - be sure to have your shades and sunblock on! Re: potential neck pain - hopefully you're not having to strain your neck too much to capture their glory.  

If you prefer to watch the air show in the comfort of your home and via the television (i.e., KRON4 - San Francisco Bay Area News), the added bonus: commentary about the demonstrations. 

Unfortunately, there have been mishaps... http://www.blueangels-usn.org/accident_history.html
author: Pina U.

description:
I grew up watching the Blue Angels. Every year, my parents would take my big bro and I to the Marina Green, and we'd watch these badasses do their awesome tricks and formations. 

So loud, they make my butthole pucker up!

Nearly every country has a military. You gotta protect your ground right? Might as well be badasses at it! 

Chit, I love America.
author: Sheila S.

description:
FA-18s flying 700 mph over San Francisco?  Sign me up!  It really doesn't get much better then seeing these amazingly talented pilots showing their skills off on a beautiful fall afternoon.  To you people complaining about the noise...really??  If it bugs you that much leave town for a few days, the rest of us will have a blast without you.

Bottom line: Blue Angels = Badass.  Also gotta give some props to the guys flying Fat Albert... Never knew a C130 could maneuver like that :D
author: Evan Z.

description:
Power, skill, and Bay backdrop made for a great show.  It made me question why I never became a fighter pilot.  Oh yeah, to start, I am way too frightened of actual combat!!!  Therefore, I respect what the Blue Angels represent and thank them as well as all the others who serve.  
And yes... I went home and watched Top Gun! 

On a side note: tax payer dollars, interruption of convos and nap time, crying babies, fear that we are being bombed?????? I thought I was going to browse through these reviews for tips and food suggestions.  
- when broken down from Federal Budget, to Defense Budget (a tiny fraction of it) then to an individuals tax dollars per year it boils down to 0.000x per tax dollar.  
- I have nothing to say about convos and naps...that's way too easy
- babies, I love them but I'm pretty sure crying is a response to most stimuli/needs.  
- and some people think they are being bombed when this is a planned event that represents the greatest Military presence per mile????
author: Melissa R.

description:
Captain America will be leading the Blue-Angels into Fleet-Week

http://images.yelp.com/photo?id=BcB_uad4eNwEexFNGhllDg&s=l
author: Matt G.

description:
We cope with the following in San Francisco on a monthy basis - with judgment on my part of this writing:

Our streets clogged with bicycles discouraging people  spend their money in the city from surrounding areas once a month.

Meter maids that live and breathe closing the budget gap by ticketing everything in sight.

Protests, and I believe in the First Amendment - just wish people took what they state for seriously and compassionately when communicating their views - that appear to be the best way to meet someone if dating has been "challenging." 

So what is the issue of the Blue Angels drawing thousands of people into the city, who are spending money in a city starving for business, that enjoy an air show? Mind boggling! Some of these protesters of the Blue Angels are ticked off Veterans whose inner child is still crying - not from their military service - rather there deep rooted child hood issues that they brought with them when they joined the military.

Let the vast majority of San Francisco Bay Area residents and many visitors enjoy Fleet Week and a top notch air show ONCE a year. After all, we tolerate quite a bit here on a monthly basis.
author: Michael G.

description:
Blue Angels make car alarms go off, birds act crazy, & kids flock to windows during class.

The Blue Angels can actually stop me from doing anything, so I can look to the sky. Have you seen so many people look at the sky all at once???

I searched through yelp talk to find a GOOD place to watch The Blue Angels. I didn't want to go ALL THE WAY to Fisherman's Wharf to see these, I would have to take the bus all the way there and back. I can see them pretty much anywhere, but I wanted the best seat in the house without paying for seats near the Pier. I opted to go to Crissy Fields, since that area is NICE and there is parking.

PARKING TOOK FOREVER TO FIND. I live in the Sunset and it took 1.5hours to get home, we eventually found a short cut near the Presidio. If we didn't find that shortcut near the residential area, we would still be there now.

Fog sure did its job today. The fog was too thick for the Blue Angels to fly =[ They were only able to fly twice. I was waiting there forever wondering why they didn't come again, since it's not suppose to end until 4PM, it was only 3:20? I don't know if I can come again, knowing fog may cancel the show.

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article/article?f=/c/a/2009/10/10/MNPR1A41TF.DTL
author: Kylie L.

description:
I think it's nice that the Blue Angels come around to different ports every year and conduct fleet week to show what discipline and training our Naval and military service in general has to offer. After all, we pay for it and we see very little of it in glory except for events like fleet week as the rest of the time all we hear of are wars in other countries and how many people have been injured or killed.

I enjoy the shows that the Blue Angels put on and I think that they do some incredible things with their planes which show their skills and training. I think just by judging how they fly, the uniformity and closeness as well as the tricks that they do, I don't think anyone here can say they can do it better than the Blue Angels so I don't see any reason to rate them poorly.

However, if you dislike noise, then you would definitely be quite annoyed when the Angels come to your city because for a week it will be much nosier than usual, all around town. 

I think it's worthwhile to check it out at least once in your life.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Anyone who doesn't love the Blue Angels and Fleet Week is NOT a true San Franciscan.  Simple as that.

Love,
A Native Born and Bred San Franciscan
author: Ryan D.

description:
I know nothing about flying and flying close together (if anything like driving close together in formation) is even more impressive.

This was the highlight of the show and these guys put on an excellent show.
It was worth setting up early for a good spot.

I think I could watch them over and over and still be amazed.
author: Nick L.

description:
Good show in 2012 for San Francisco and cannot wait for 2013 Fleet Week. For those who say the Blue Angels are annoying. You know what? Go live in Iraq! In this country we fight for freedom. If it wasn't for these guys who risk their lives for us you won't be living in a comfort chair, you will be Bin Laden b***h and slave! Or he might kill you when your useless to him. He will take your kids and use them as target practice. I'm so proud to have a Navy and military fighter jets flying around knowing protection is always guarantee for US Americans and I don't see why many of you don't see that. US Navy Seals for killing Bin Laden so we can maintain our freedom.

Also if there is am major disaster in your area, who will be helping you with food and medical assistance. Our military! That is right! During the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake, lot of military personal came to SF to help us. You stupid people should be damn thankful. But if a disaster happens, I really hope you don't get help and strive on your own. Since if you feel Fleet Week is bad, I swear to damn God all of you will be damn happy to see the US military help save your sorry a$$.

So yes.. Keep Fleet Week in San Francisco. Wonderful tradition and many of people enjoy the show and honoring the men and women in the armed forces.
author: Nick J.

description:
Are you kidding me!?!?! 

If you don't like the Blue Angels, then you've just haven't watched them from the right spot. The BEST spot in the Bay for you to watch The Blue Angels to see just how good these guys are is at the Golden Gate Bridge. 

To see high powered F-18's go near supersonic about 100 feet over the bridge is a sight every person should see before the die! And then The Blue Angels will do it again, and again, and again! 

Yes, they're noisy! But, WTF! So are Muni streetcars and most of the so-called bars in San Fran. 

So? You're worried about one of the jets crashing? Well, last I heard, there were more Muni Streetcar crashes this year then Blue Angel crashes... (knock on superwood!) 

So... Stop bitching. Grab some kids. And head down to the Golden Gate Bridge or Marina to see what true skill and professionalism looks like. Even if they don't fly in the fog... LOL 

(btw... people. Take my advice. If you want to see the Blue Angels WITHOUT the crowds, I suggest you watch them during one of their "practice" performance generally on Thursday and Friday before fleet week. Why? Because in the world of aviation there is no such thing as "practice" once your in the air. It's the actual show.... Anchor's Away!)
author: Black K.

description:
I saw the Blue Angels once from Crissy Field before, and I was impressed. 

However, if you want to enjoy the full and TRUE experience of seeing Blue Angels in SF, you got to watch it from SF Maritime National Park. 

The stone bench seats were perfect spots! the Blue Angels flied just in front and above you! The 6 blue angels formation were the BEST!!! 

Invest in a long lenses camera if you want great pictures. I only had my cellphone camera, so it didn't do any justice to them.

Note: traffic was crazy but it was worth the trip
author: Coco L.

description:
I didn't think it was worth a Saturday afternoon since I was only in SF for two days to visit my friend but it was worth it.  We waited an hour for the show on a pier in the shade behind a building (very cold) and had a great time watching the show.  The tricks weren't too diverse but it was great to see the show at least once and I had a great time with my friend.

Afterward, we went to the Somersault concert.  Had a nice afternoon.
author: Phillip N.

description:
This year my son and I watched the Blue Angels from a boat out in the bay. What a freakin' awesome experience! Not only were we buzzed by one of the solo pilots several times, but their delta formation (all six aircraft in a tight triangle formation) flew right over our boat! I mean, they were so close that I could've seen the expressions on the pilot's faces!

TRULY. EFFIN'. EPIC!!!

Oh, and to those one star reviewers who say that the jets make too much "noise", I have to disagree with your opinion. To me, a Marine Corps veteran and aviation buff, the reassuring sound of an F/A-18 Hornet flying overhead is like sweet music, conjuring up images of sunshine and lollipops!
author: Jay D.

description:
ive been watching the Blue Angels every year since i was a little kid! Fleet week is one of the best times of the year, getting to see a free show in the sky and getting to meet and buy our servicemen and women a beer when i see em. all you people speaking ill of the military should be ashamed, theyre here to show us what they can do, to make us proud! they deserve our support, from the deepest parts of our hearts and souls!!!!!!!

get used to it, the Angels and their Fleet are here to stay for decades to come!!!!!
author: Dom B.

description:
LOGIC: Without the Blue Angels, there would be no Fleet Week. I love Fleet Week. Therefore, I love the Blue Angels.

They are truly an amazing spectacle as they fly through the sky in awe-inspiring formations... so special!

The most phenomenal things to witness in the sky (in my opinion!):
day-time: parrots overhead, Blue Angels
night-time: shooting stars, fireworks
author: Meghan P.

description: Entertaining and amazing to see their tricks during fleet week in sf. Thanks for the awe moments!
author: James L.

description:
Back in 1979-1984 (I don't remember which year exactly) they buzzed North Beach.  Right on the deck down Columbus Avenue!  Dianne Feinstein was outraged!  

I love watching them from the office.  There will be no work done this week.  I've watched them from USF, and I've watched them turn over the Beach Chalet, so low you can almost touch them.  Once, in the middle of a turn, the pilot waved at the specators on the ground!
author: David D.

description:
I am going to stay out of the military recruitment/we need the tourist revenue debate and base my 1 star on this: when they fly over my little studio I feel terrified, and no, I haven't lived through a war. It's loud and scary and I cringe inadvertantly and I worry about the pilots making a misjudgment and hurting themselves and us (and smashing through my window). 
I apologize to those who love the show...but it is a relief to me when they leave.
author: joanne m.

description:
I'm not excited you're in town. I hate it, listening to you fly overhead makes me wish I lived outside the city. And why are you in town for so long isn't two days enough?!? 

Ugh I don't like the military and I don't want to have to listen to planes all weekend just because I live in the city!
author: Meghan A.

description:
I love the Blue Angels, and I love America.

Meghan doesn't love America, and you know what, I think the feeling's mutual...
author: Jillian M.

description:
What I wouldn't give to be a passenger in one of these.  They are parked outside one of my company's buildings at the airport.  Yes, it costs millions to fuel, produce, etc, but the local economy more than benefits.  They use the Lone Mountain campus at USF as a guide to know where to turn around.  That led to many interesting moments during school.

Just wish I could go see them this year, but my mom just HAD to be born on October 9, and my niece also just HAD to be born on October 5.  No Blue Angles for me this year!
author: Michael M.

description:
Bbbrrrrrooooommmmm! Whooosssshhhhh!

That's the sound of 1,300 gallons of jet fuel being spent per plane, per day. Woohoo!!!

Just a comment, not a criticism, cuz I do LIKE the Blue Angels.
(Disclaimer: yes, I do have relatives serving in the military)

Since today is the last day of Fleet Week, I thought I'd write a review about the Blue Angels. I do enjoy watching their air show, except when they flew too close to my old office building in previous years and rattled my nerves. At my new office building I don't mind at all, I can't hear a thing. So they're A-okay.

I ignore the militaristic implications and recruitment issues involved. I just admire the acrobatics. Might as well enjoy it, since our taxes are paying for it. For some reason the Blue Angels have not suffered as many accidents as the Thunderbirds (since 1972, 2 casualties for BA vs. 10 for the USAF's T.), they use different training procedures and aircrafts, just a coincidence perhaps? who knows.

Keep them flying over SF every year!!
Ignore the sour pussies like Chris Daly!
author: Luis C.

description:
Apparently, many of you enjoy seeing big machines go really fast and make loud sounds. That's nice for you, but isn't why there's NASCAR and Michael Bay movies? Some of us do not think "COOOOL!!!" when fighter jets buzz our city. My first thought is "oh crap, World War III has just started." I just wonder how all the homeless veterans with PTSD deal with these war games.

So I don't enjoy the Blue Angels much, but I do like Hardly Strictly Bluegrass. Since I enjoy bluegrass music, would I advocate for Emmylou Harris' voice to be amplified to ear-splitting, window shaking volume and pumped into every corner of the city? Of course not, because I have respect for others.

The reason I bring up Hardly Strictly Bluegrass is because, once again, due to godawful planning, they both fall on the same weekend this year. My dislike of the Blue Angels got ratcheted up to pure hatred at HSB a few years back when Elvis Costello's singing was literally drowned out the sonic booms of fighter jets behind him.

What is so funny about peace, love and understanding, anyway? And why is a celebration of killing machines more important than music?
author: Scott S.

description: Thank heavens this annual insult to citizens is over for another year.  The Blue Angels are a phenomenal waste of taxpayer money. They are too loud and serve no purpose. Those hot shot pilots and their multimillion dollar playthings should be in Afghanistan earning their keep.  If these guys want to be entertainers, let them join Pussy Galore's Flying Circus.  These kinds of demonstrations of military strength and might are what one would expect from North Korea or Russia; not the United States. This type of saber rattling might play in the sticks but San Francisco is much too sophisticated to be subjected to it every Columbus Day Weekend.
author: Richard L. D.

description:
WOW! I can't believe all the ultra-liberal communist one and two star reviewers on the Blue Angels.  These freaks make the Bay Area the laughing stock of the U.S.  
These uneducated, NIMBY morons should educate themselves and if they have an issue with the Blue Angels during Fleet Week, leave your precious rented SF domain for the weekend and go somewhere...like East Oakland!!

The Blue Angels have been around since 1946(!) and are good will ambassadors for the Navy and Marines...the same military which gave the liberal-communist one star reviewers a free country to express their hate!

Keep on flying Angels! You guys are the best!
author: Eric B.

description:
I just sat in the windy ass cold weather by the Hyde Street Pier today to see the Blue Angels pass by 3 times and that was it! The Blue Angels portion of the air show was to start at 3:00 and last til 4:00. Unfortunately, economic times are rough and there were very few sponsors, so this show was drastically cut back. The freakin fog caused the Blue Angels to be in the air for only 6 minutes!

In addition, sitting near a couple of smokers made it even worst!

Overall, the show was nice, but the weather and scale of the show was a MAJOR disappointment THIS year. Last years show was 100X better.

I has some aweome garlic crab fries...but the freakin garlic is still with me! UGH!

I've added some pics from LAST year show for your viewing pleasure.
author: Peter L.

description:
You're only practicing today but you still get my pulse racing and make my heart skip a beat!
I can't help but run from window to window following your flight!

America! F*** Yeah!
author: Edi B.

description: I hate the Blue Angels.  I teach refugees and immigrants, many of whom are from countries that we bombed heavily (Vietnam, Cambodia. Laos, Iraq, etc.).  Each time the obnoxious planes fly overhead, I think of how many people been damaged psychologically or physically or been killed by our addiction to war.  I cannot believe San Francisco allows this.  Send the Blue Angels to Hayward.  They need the money more than we do!
author: Nelson K.

description:
RIP to the Blue Angels pilots who have died.

They have been around since I was young and I have enjoyed watching them.  But is entertaining people worth risking your life for?  I guess for stuntmen, daredevils and pilots like the Blue Angels it is.  Makes life more interesting to watch people risk their lives.  

Anyways, respect to the fallen.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
ALL BLEEDING-HEART LIBERALS UNITE!  

I got here to look for the best places to see the Blue Angel and found libs complaining.   UGH....   Please, enough already.    You knew the Angels will be here before you've moved to SF.   They've announced a year in advance when they will be in town.    

Here's a solution for next year:  Why not gather up all your bleeding hearts and ride in your flower covered buses and drive to the Humbolt County for the weekend.   Really, they have all the MJ that you can smoke.    

It'll be your 4:20 for the entire weekend.   Imagine that.   Problem solved.

Remember "your city" isn't really yours.   SF is ours -- not only people with bleeding hearts can live and breath there.   Guess what, everyone is welcome at the burbs.
author: John W.

description:
After living in both Seattle for "Sea Fair" and San Francisco for "Fleet Week" i feel so lucky to have been able to witness the blue angels twice in one year.

Firstly, I wish money was spent on health instead of weapons but since I'm a tech guy I have to be amazing at the technology employed for this air show. Give the pilots credit; they do an amazing job and I can't understand how anyone cannot be impressed by them.

Seriously folks; look at what the wright brothers started just over 100 years ago and where we are now (please ignore the war aspect for a second)

PS: I also added some more pics of the show :)
author: Bryan B.

description:
Blue Angels rock as well as the entire air show. I am a liberal but I love airplanes. Maybe coz my father is a pilot and I grew up in the airport. Anyway, I am looking forward to the next year's air show. 
Everyone, stop whining and just enjoy this air ballet.
author: Ksenia A.

description:
I always forget about Fleet Week until I am suddenly bombarded with sounds of war planes drowning out my otherwise average day. 
One side of me thinks they look cool. It's fun to watch. The Blue Angels are absolutely all American! America... Fuck yeah! 

But the other part of me is annoyed with the ear deafening(Hello! Noise pollution!) jets and their plumes of toxic smoke. Oh the pollutions these jets cause! 
Everyone is free to feel how they want about the show, but honestly, cant the money it takes to have these kinds of shows be better spent on something else?
author: joanna r.

description: I wish I could give zero stars. Piercing noise pollution. Militaristic. A waste of millions of dollars. Support arts in the schools instead, feed people, house the homeless. Should be banned from the city.
author: lisa g.

description:
I love watching the blue angels, and I curse myself for always forgetting earplugs. Dammit. 
 
The last two years we have gone out on a law enforcement boat, so no margaritas for us, but thrilling to see being closer than other boats get to go. 
 
 Also it is fun to have lights and sirens on our boat, kids love to wave at us.
author: Emily L.

description:
AMAZING! Breathtaking! The Blue Angels flew so close I swear you felt like they were going to crash into the crowd. Their tricks were awesome!!

Yes it took us about 2 hours to get to the Golden Gate Bridge from the freeway. And with us not knowing they were even performing, once we got there and figured out why there was traffic and so many people, we took advantage of it. 

We found a great spot to park which was pass the overflow parking lot and the view was unbelievable. It overlooked the Golden Gate Bridge and the city. Add the warm weather and great company, it ended up to be a great day trip. Especially since one of our friends have never been to the bridge but have seen the Blue Angels in Seattle. He said that this was nothing he's ever experienced before. And I definitely concur!
author: Betty D.

description: I, like many others, hate the noise!  It's not just mildly annoying, it's completely out of control.  And if you have babies or children, you might as well just leave for the week.  I truly dread it!
author: Reannie R.

description: OMG we are under attack! The F@%#k ing Blue Angels just set off every car alarm in a 20 block radius. My ears are ringing! My child is screaming! Grandmother is cowering under her bed yelling something about the Germans? Me? I'm just trying to earn a living but my heart goes out to the terrified young and old suffering this deafening, unjustifiable, noise. How in the can this be allowed?
author: Ben S.

description:
Fuck the blue angles.
How much are we taxpayers paying for this daily?
Do they ever have to have a bake sale to raise money to buy jet fuel?
What happens when the slam and crash into a building in a large populated city?
The Govt says - oops.

FUCK THE BLUE ANGELS.
author: l H.

description:
There are a few reasons I love the Blue Angels. 

1. They are some of the most amazing pilots in the world.

2. The sound of a jet engine is like music to my ears.

3. All the liberals stay inside for the weekend meaning the city looks like a somewhat normal city like San Diego.

If I was the President, I would have the Angels hover on top of the ACLU building so those whiny little liberals would go deaf and never utter another word again.

The Angels bring about a million people into the city. Considering that the city is broke, I would rather have the Angels here than some stupid hippy festival like Lovefest.
author: Darius A.

description:
YES!! These guys are awesome!!

I had a choice to attend Fleet week in SF but decided to attend another event.

I was fortunate enough to be invited to the United Airlines Friends and Family day at SFO. Food, cars, jets, planes, music, tons of interesting things but the one thing that stood out were the Blue Angels.

The Blue Angels parked their sweet rides on the tarmac.  It was sectioned off but close enough for everyone to see and take pictures.  I love "Fat Albert" that cargo plane painted in blue and gold put a fat smile on my face.

What patrons dont see at Fleet Week at the Marina greens is the pre-show pageantry.   Yeah, that's right, pageantry.  They not only fly in formation but also perform a preflight show.  They're like freggin androids!

The patrons had the opportunity to watch them start up, take off, and do a few fly by's before heading off the Fleet Week.  Then they'll return, park, and you'll see the post flight pageantry.  God I love that word. LoL!

They were kind enough to sign autographs and take pictures for a good hour or so before flying off to Moffet field.  Bravo gentlemen!
author: Sun T.

description: Anyone familiar with the Rammstein and Ukraine Air Show Jet Disasters knows the Blue Angels show in San Francisco is an accident waiting to happen.  In those cases the victims were not a captive audience.  If these jets go down in the densely populated San Francisco Urban Landscape they may well take out multiple city blocks with a much larger loss of life than at Rammstein.  In my opinion this show is Criminal. And it's a relic of the Reagan Era. A criminal joke by the ultra right against opponents on the Left.  We need to bring the Glorification of War to a Halt.  There's nothing Glamorous about Brandishing Weapons of Mass Destruction.
author: david f.

description: Impressive! Unknown to us, we were here during Fleet week and they were practicing throughout  our stay. I didn't mind as much because the fighter pilots were flying all over San Francisco, and I was amazed, but bf didn't appreciate it as much. Seriously, the noise level was awful, car alarms were going off, parking was a pain but for the experience, I think it was worth it.
author: Sharon K.

description:
You hear that?

It's the sound of our tax money going up in smoke.

Fuck heathcare, RIGHT?!?  Let's have quasi-militaristic demonstrations of our patriotism!  Whee!!

Well, we should ALL be grateful.  At least they're not bombing the shit out of some country.

Wait.
author: d s.

description:
We were visiting SF and happened to be @ the Wharf when the Blue Angels were there.  They were freaking awesome.  I think they are awesome in general, but to be able to witness their awesomeness especially with my kids was hmmm....awesome!  

We happened to be on one of the one hour Bay Cruises just as the show was starting.  So we really didn't have to brave the crowds of people at the pier.   The Angels flew over us and next to us a couple times.  They were so loud and it was totally exhilarating.  I loved hearing all the cheers and excitement.  It brings a tear to my eye.  

It freaks me out to see them fly so close together in formation that I'm just in awe every moment they are flying.  

I love how the Wharf brings so many of us tourists in one spot that it really made me happy to see foreigners get excited about OUR military show!  Yes we are so awesome!  Go USA!
author: Michelle V.

description:
What? Huh? What? You think what about the Blue Angels? Yeah well I can't hear you CAUSE I AM NEARLY DEAF from days of sonic booming. It's so much fun when my whole flat shakes. MMMM I just love that heavenly Blue Angel scent of jet fuel lingering in the air for hours and hours. Nice and soothing to all the animals in the area too - the birds in particular really go for it. Granted, I live in Russian Hill, so I get the full throttle surround sound version each and every goddamn year! ACK!!!

Ooooh, ooooh, soooo exciting to see the big planes go whirly whirl whirl. Wonder if someone will die this year, they have before ya know.  Always fun for the kiddies to witness - there can never be enough childhood trauma really.  Yippee let's glorify military maneuvers. GO TO HELL Blue Angels!  You outdated circus of testosterone and noise.
author: wendella a.

description:
You are nothing but cheerleaders for the military industrial complex, something shiny to distract the rubes while the pentagon picks your pockets. If you are really "the best of the best" why aren't you helping out in the wars?

Please stop flying over my house
author: Manny F.

description:
My thoughts on jingoism, territorial pissings, and the insane price of fuel notwithstanding...

I think tit for tat. I think that if the military, who has (at best) an awkward relationship with San Francisco, gets to spend a few days of each year scaring the crap of us, then we get to throw an entirely US-funded dance party on an aircraft carrier (including transport to and from). This party should be just far enough out into international waters that we can make Burning Man blush.

(hums "Wouldn't It Be Nice". Is interrupted by some butthole's "recruiting efforts" on behalf of the U.S. Navy and Marine Corps.)
author: jason l.

description:
OK, I gotta admit where I'm coming from on this review.  I grew up in Oshkosh, WI, which for those who don't know is the home of EAA Oshkosh (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oshkosh_Airshow), the largest airshow in the US and quite probably the world.  It's a celebration of flight in all its forms, everything from cessnas, to homebuilts, to stunt pilots, to the largest gathering of WW2 aircraft anywhere, to the most modern military jets.
Going to watch these planes do their thing every year as a kid was totally inspiring, and a large part of why I ended up becoming an engineer.

So that said, I love the Blue Angels.  Sure, they're military, and they're expensive, and they pollute, and they're loud.  But (excepting the military part) so are fireworks.  And fireworks are awesome.  Similarly, astoundingly high performance jets doing amazingly complex aerobatics at wickedly high speeds are also awesome.  Not only in the "we as humans are able to create things which are capable of this" way, but also in the "the people who fly these are unbelievably skilled" sort of way.
Plus, the kid in me totally loves it when he sees a jet streak silently past, and then a few seconds later hears the huge-ass roar.  So cool.

And for those of you complaining about the "environmental waste", lets do a quick back-of-the-envelope calculation.  There are only 6 of them.  Each plane carries about 10,000lb of fuel.  For comparison, a 747 uses about 100,000lb of fuel on a 5-hour flight.  So worst case, if they managed to use their entire fuel supply each time, each air show or practice is the rough equivalent of one 747 flying from SF to New York.  Compared to the number of commercial jets flying around the globe in any given moment, that's reasonably insignificant.  And it's a hell of a lot less particulate pollution than your average fireworks show.  Just some food for thought.
author: Don H.

description:
Sorry guys - Can't empathize with the Blue Angel hatred because I 
LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT!!!!!!!

I love it every year when the Blue Angels come to town - and I'm a lefty pacifist - I just adore the speed and the roar - like a roller coaster or a demolition derby or enduro racing!  

They make me say WOOHOO!!
author: Robyn C.

description:
(Old Man Voice) Hey, you kids! Get outta my sky!!!

(Douchebag Country Singer Voice) They Are Heee-roes!
author: Jeremy W.

description:
You people need to lighten the fuck up.  There is nothing better than six fighter jets screaming over a major city.  It's an AIR SHOW, people.  You don't like it, get out of town for the weekend.  Those of you who blame them for the war in Iraq clearly have IQs of room temperature.

Your little dog barks because the planes are too loud?  Deal with it for six hours out of the year.  Your kid screams because it's too loud?  Did you ever pause to think that maybe if you couldn't afford to live in S.F. proper you'd have to live in Bayview and hear the air traffic at SFO constantly?  Deal with it.

I mean, I guess it's sort of like that in Basra every night, but it's too hot out there for me, so I'll watch the Blue Angels in S.F. instead.
author: Geoff K.

description:
My wedding day was at the conclusion of Fleet Week at Black Point Battery in Fort Mason (it was not planned that way.) So every time I hear the low flying roar of turbine jet engines I think to myself, "Aw, that is SOOO romantic." *sigh*

To those who are upset about them wasting our tax dollars...at least they're not bombing shit.
author: Josua P.

description:
Inviting everyone in the Bay Area out for a BLAST during FLEET WEEK! I am on the board of the Maritime National Park Assoc.. We are hosting an event at the museum with tons of food, drinks and fun! Global Gourmet is providing the food. Come enjoy our Bar and Sky/Sea view with wrap around deck seating with no crowds!
The price to the public is $85 adults (half for kids). Well, I have limited seats available for $60.00 with half that for kids (just use the special code: BLueLME when ordering using this link:      www.brownpapertickets.com/event/201399

Hope to see my folks there!!!!! Please let me know if you can make it!
author: Sanford L.

description:
It is a show of incredible skill and dedication and you have to admire it.
And they would spend the money on training flights even if there were blue angels.  And the Navy has announced that the Blue Angels beginning next year will fly using 50% Bio Fuel/J4.
If you have issues with the Military, by all means express your opinions - that is what this country is all about.  But add up the pluses and minuses.  It brings people into San Francisco from Gilroy, the Valley, Sacramento and they spend money.  This helps local businesses and the people who work in those establishments.  And it contributes to the city's coffers.
If the noise  bothers you get earplugs.  And the snarky comments about smelling J4, are you sure it is not Muni your smelling.  
And the trade off between guns and butter.  How about lets turn the bankers upside down and shake out all the money they stole from us.  And how is that these radical right tea party nuts keep getting elected to congress and blocking anything from happening.  You should be a living representation of the solution you are promoting and based on your snarky tone, why should I follow you?
author: bart b.

description:
Love them. And it'll be a cold night in hell before I blame them for our:

air and noise pollution problems
war 
babies crying
stupid cats cowering under beds
deficit
child porn industry
terminator for governor
expanding consumerism

Have I forgotten anything? I sure hope I have so someone can PM me reminding me of our country's failures. 

And come on, big jets flying super fast are so cool!
author: Ali L.

description:
Yeah plane tricks are cool as a kid, but as an adult how can one cheer for a killing machine. The military might as well bring out tanks and start blowing shit up right there on the bay. Wooowweee what a loud explosion! That killing machine can kill hundreds of people, and more efficient than previous machines. 
Blue angels dont, but all those 'fighter planes' are designed to KILL. Kill people. That fancy arial flip, to kill a human. That super sonic speed, to kill a human. 
Just because someone pimps out an electric chair and creates a whole weekend event showcasing the pimpage, doesnt make it any less lethal
author: Tamir M.

description: I would say that Fleet Week brings with it every low consciousness suburbanite within 200 miles to the city. What a terrible waste of my taxpayer dollars. And these neanderthal Blue Angels (Devils) flying a few hundred feet over rooftops is the most obscene gesture of all to us citizens. I realize that the military is a necessary evil but to glorify these testosterone-filled idiots is another thing all together. My windows and doors rattle, and pictures fall off the walls. If they really must fly so low, why don't they do it over the bay or over open space?  It would obviously be safer and more sane. I'm also a fourth generation San Franciscan.
author: Tony G.

description:
I almost crapped my pants last year when the cowboys in blue planes buzzed the Financial District on a weekday morning.

I hadn't even had my morning coffee yet, when some flight jock in an F-whatever conducted mock strafing runs really fricken close to the skyscrapers.

A bunch of us yuppie scum ducked for cover.

I definitely felt under attack, and the fight-or-flight response had activated in all our bodies.

Aren't the 9/11 attacks still too recent to be flying high-speed aircraft so close to densely populated business districts?

It was hard to calm down the whole day, with everyone on edge and jumpy.

I'm not opposed to air shows over air force bases, or the ocean, but come on folks.  Over the Financial District during the work week?  The risk to human lives is unnecessary.

And for those people who say precision flying is safe, fire up your Google search and look up The Thunderbirds.

It's all fun and games 'till a pilot trying to show off accidentally takes out the Transamerica Pyramid.

It's all part of the "look at me! look at me!" mentality that a number of erection-challenged males who rev up their obnoxiously loud motorcycles seem to have.

I say we all chip in and buy these guys a bunch of Viagra and be done with it.
author: Justin C.

description:
I swear to whatever God is listening.....

About 2 minutes ago, they almost landed in my garden right here in Bernal Heights.  Thanks for freaking my dog out. He's too old for this and he's shaking like a little leaf!!!

I hate this crap more than I can explain.
author: Abby W.

description:
Being a San Francisco BAR (Born And Raised), I love the Blue Angels!  I'm willing to bet that all of you bitter yelpers aren't from around here.  

Fleet week is not about showing support for the current administration or their agenda, its for showing support of the men and women who risk their lives so that we can complain about awesomely loud jets on a beautiful San Francisco October day!

As someone else put it - if you don't like the jets go on vacation during fleet week!  For me, I'll stay and enjoy the show.
author: Anthony B.

description:
Air shows used to be cool when I was 6.

Not so much anymore especially since now I know that they used our tax money to keep them jets flying.

Someone in my class said this today: "If I had a boatload of money, the first thing I'd do is to buy the Blue Angels so I won't have to hear them anymore".
I'd contribute about 73 cents for that cause.
author: Ari C.

description:
F*king Go Away!!!!!
Your lack of respect for residents living downtown in SF is appalling. SF should ban you. Every year the noise and lack of respect makes me want to hunt down every one of your homes and spend 4 days a piece at your residencies making window shaking noises at random and unpredictable intervals. I'm tired of having my ears attacked and my pets upset on an annual basis by the military.
author: Alice F.

description:
Alright - at the risk of sounding like grandma Genevieve here:  can these menaces get ANY louder?  Jesus.  

Yea yea...they're "so cool", and "symbolize the American spirit", and "represent military pride".  Thats all great, but in my opinion: they are too damn loud, and one day is enough for me.  Do they really have to practice all fucking week?  "The Blue Terrorizers": a more appropriate name.  Really.  Not looking forward to that sonic boom later this weekend.  And another thing, I wonder how much the city pays every year to have them here...kind of a waste in my opinion...not to mention the wasted jet fuel & environmental impact.

Also, they scare the shit out of my cat (and I'm sure all the other wild animals in the area) and I can't let her out while they're flying because she'll get scared and run off.  So in addition to the deafening noise that prevents me from taking a nap, I have to listen to my fucking cat whine for 3 days about going out.  Not really a fan.
author: Genevieve M.

description:
A cherished childhood memory, and that alone is enough to go against all of Yelpdom.

Back when The Presidio was still an Army base, my mom and I would head down to Crissy Field to watch them fly. It was followed by a visit to BK on the hill.
author: Keane L.

description:
NO stars!  NONE!

Makes dogs and cats go insane and live in fear for four days, and people drive extra-stupidly because they're trying to see the planes, and the whole Marina is a douchebag parking lot (right? but more so than usual).

As a kid, I recall you were free to enjoy an air show in, like, Santa Rosa if you felt like it. What happened to that? You should have to drive at least 30 minutes out of the city to experience planes careening around overhead, not be blindsided by screaming loudness of unknown origin in the middle of a cosmopolitan goddamn city.  It bugs!

On a serious note: I know a guy less than a year out of Iraq who had to pull over and spend a half hour suppressing total panic due to PTSD.  That seems like a good enough reason to move it to a place where participation would be voluntary. That way the 730,000 of us who don't want to deal with it aren't forced to do so.
author: Teal H.

description:
Ditto what Cornelius said!

Blue Angels, please go away.  We got tired of the testosterone propaganda fanfare 10 years ago.  No, 15.
author: Melanie C.

description:
I suggested that my friends and I write a Haiku about these crazy guys.  Here's mine:
Flying over and over our city
A simple mistake will send them crashing
They will kill us all
author: Ed B.

description:
I love to watch the Blue Angels - and I have a great vantage point from the attic window of my house. I love the precision, the grace, the power, the daring, the noise, and the speed. Most of all I love the speed - the acceleration. It fills me with awe to see a vehicle with a woman or man inside it scream from the Castro to the Marina in just a few seconds and in just a few more climb thousands of feet into the sky, before becoming a tiny speck that my old eyes can then no longer see. To be there and then be gone.

This fills me with joy and wonder. It does not fill my heart with patriotism. It does not make my glands swell and I do not feel the testosterone suddenly surge through through my body. But it does make me smile.

But I am conflicted. For then I remember what these machines represent. The terror of what this show means to onlookers in other parts of the world, like some Red Square parade - let alone the horror that these weapons can bring. So while they sometimes bring me joy, they can also make me sick to my stomach.

If it were a matter of you can't have one without the other, then I could do without.
author: Kingpin X.

description:
ROCK ON!
I love the feeling of my house shaking!
All I can say is WOW !
I want to take a ride on one!
.
PS - This has nothing to do with the war on iraq, - which I am totally against!!!
And to all the tree huggers complaining about the jet fuel, we live 10 miles from SFO !! There are hundreds of jets taking off daily..start complaining about those, or go over to Berkeley and climb up on some of those trees and protest.
author: Pug P.

description:
I hate them with a fiery passion that festers deep within my soul like gonorrhea.

They're war planes, y'know? They should be off, I dunno, annoying Iraq into submission or something. If a terrorist shouts "JIHAD!" and nobody can hear it because a bunch of planes are flying around being generally obnoxious, will anyone die?
author: Liz A.

description:
I think Sideshow Bob said it best:

"Air show?  Buzz-cut Alabamians spewing colored smoke from their
whiz jets to the strains of "Rock You Like A Hurricane?"  What kind of countrified rube is still impressed by that?"

I would give it zero stars if I could, but I guess it's worth the one star for the fact that I always snicker when the planes roar by and the music cues up in my head: "Here I am....duh nuh nuh...rock you like a hurricane..."
author: DD B.

description:
Anti-war people hate the Blue Angels?  Please.  What they do has very little if anything to do with the military.  Sure, they use military hardware.  But there is little you touch in your daily lives that wasn't developed by or for the military.

As for the pollution, how about removing every unnecessary SUV from the road and enjoying the once a year demonstration of precision and skill.

They are practicing right now... AWESOME!
author: Anthony R.

description:
1 and 5 at the same time equals 3.

Loud... annoying... silly.... 1.

ZOOOM and getting my eyes to gaze desperately while craning my neck from my office desk?

5

I hate Chris Daly?  That is a different issue.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description:
I detest the Blue Angels. 
Sure, I lothe what they represent... but I can go ahead and skip that whole line of argument, because I would still hate them if they were representing the Dali Lama.
The Blue Angels are a loud & gassy houseguest who doesn't even ask and always stays too long.
author: Sarah G.

description:
As far as I can tell, US is the only country where we get to see something as cool as Blue Angels fly around in formations above a crowded urban city for pure entertainment purposes. How cool is dat!?

Yeah I am also against the war and shit. Call me hypocrite if it pleases you. But looking at F/A-18 from pure technological advancement stand point, it is an astonishing piece of engineering work. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F/A-18)

Talking of Blue Angels, here's something...
http://youtube.com/watch?v=zZRuta2Zzbw
author: Ryo S.

description:
I'm not going to include any of my personal thoughts on the war or the military in general, as I don't feel it's particularly relevant here. 

The Blue Angels are a precision team who train to do shows, so that's what I'm rating them on.

- Are they good at their precision flying? Yes. One star.
- Do they fly just over the Bay? No.
- Do they fly low over the city and cause my ears to ring? Yes.
- Do I live anywhere near the Wharf? No.
- Should my ears be ringing if I don't live anywhere near the Wharf? NO.
- Is there anyway to escape the noise during Fleet Week? NO. Not if you don't have a car to get the hell out of the city for a few days...
- Does it last just the one day of the "planned show"? NO.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
I must admit that what they do is freaking amazing. Did you know that if the guy in the front flew straight into the ground every other plane that was following him would do the same thing because only the guy in front is looking ahead, the rest are focused purely on the wing of the plane in front of them. That said...the guy in front should fly into the ground the week before mother f*ckin fleet week because if I have to listen to them fly over my house one more time I'll get my own jet fighting plane thingy and shoot them out of the sky.

UPDATE: Unfortunately I posted this only days before the Blue Angel crashed into the ground. I swear I had nothing to do with it. 

I have a lot of sympathy for his family and friends. On the other hand, when you are flying like that you always have to keep in mind that this could happen.
author: Laura D.

description: Loved it!  Great weather, great crowd, great views, and high-powered, precision jet flying.  Whew.
author: Daryl E.

description:
DAMN YOUUUUUUU!!!

"It's all because of you,
I'm feeling sad and blue..."

Because I had to work...
I was stuck in traffic for 3 hours on Saturday. 
And I was stuck again in traffic for 2 hours on Sunday.
author: Nance W.

description:
I spent far too much energy trying to keep up the farce that the Blue Angels are a "dude" thing. 
Perhaps I was also trying to convince myself...truth is though, the Blue Angels are like fireworks...loud, flashy, and explosive. 
I had the pleasure of watching them this weekend from a Marina rooftop with a few friends (mostly women) and more than a few Red Stripes. The sun was shining, my hangover was fading, and the guac was spicy. Watching the spiraling nose dives reminded me of how much I do enjoy the ground and how happy I was that my hangover was mild. 
Inspiring a sense of awe and wonder, the view, the planes, the company (and the beer), and the sun made for a truly perfect Sunday afternoon.
author: Jessa B.

description:
Our tax dollars (not) at work.

Sure it is neat-o and flashy, but is it really right for billions of dollars to be spent on this and other government PR?  Have you seen the cuts planned for important things ?

Interesting links:
http://www.hackworth.com/19mar01.html
http://www.ou.edu/deptcomm/dodjcc/groups/00C2/AIR.HTM
author: GIR ..

description:
Blue Angels today
on the Bay

Flew with such skill
terrifyingly if you will

We waited for days
Sounds of jets in the SF haze

Come back year after year
Stop protesting you hear?
author: Mandy S.

description:
A bad reflection on the US: rich, entitled fly-boys scaring all the animals out of their wits.

SUPPORT THE TROOPS, not the defense contractors.
author: Richard S.

description:
Why I can't give negative feedback? 
Totally stupid idea of this kind show!!! 

Are there too much oil to waste?
So many animals are terrified including my cats and dog.
So many people living in Marina area, if ther is an accident.......
Why should we put up with this kind of noise every year?
author: Bruce T.

description:
Top air show in the world, period.  What a great free show over Fleet Week.  If you never have seen them, it is a "must do".  On a clear day, when they fly over the Bay, you are thankful to be an American. 

Awe inspiring, and when you see them, just remember it took those pilots a lot of work to get there.  Four years college, 3 years various flight schools, at least 5 more years flying and being separated from families. Then selection from over 2000 qualified pilot applicants. 

Please join me in saluting all the military personnel associated with the BA.  Be thankful you have a free city like San Francisco to live and work. 

Blue Angels are a symbol of our military strength, that no matter what, allows us all the freedoms we have. 

Folks:  my dad served in WWII.  He always told me to remember:

Freedom is never Free!
author: John G.

description:
They're not a joke.  They're the punchline to a joke:

What's loud, boring, and a huge waste of everyone's time?

[I'm bumping it up from a 1 to a 2 because a friend went on a Hornblower cruise, and her kids had a great time with the jets buzzing the boat. -- just not my cup of tea]
author: Tim G.

description:
They only get 4 stars because they aren't allowed to do any of the fun stuff any more- flying under bridges and through the financial district.  

Where to see them? I haven't found the perfect spot yet. Ft. Point is good unless the fog rolls in, which is often. Angel Island is pretty good, but you have to ruin your buzz running for the last ferry back to Tiburon. The Marina is too hard to deal with. On the water has been the best spot yet, but it isn't always possible.  I'm still searching- when I find it, I'll let you know. 

And for all you people bitching about them- they've been coming here for how many years? And you've lived here how long? Yeah- I'm guessing they were here first. And it's not like people don't know when they'll be showing up- they do post the schedule, and they are here pretty much every year.  I mean, myself, I practically live under a rock, but I make a point to find out about events that will affect my life.
author: Beetle B.

description:
Growing up in Seattle, I just thought the Blue Angels was a Seafair kind of thing. Maybe since Seattle I saw them over the water, they seemed more spectacular then. Watched them from a rooftop in
Pacific Heights. Ehhh, not so much here. 

Good thing I was with fun company & drinking Anchorsteam.
author: Lisa V.

description:
OK, so I'm really torn.  As a pretty liberal gal I am, of course, against the war and the dynasty running it.  And the Blue Angels could probably be considered a pretty strong military symbol.

Every year the planes practice for a couple days before fleet week... right over our office.  Literally buzzing our rickety old building... I mean this building shakes when the wind blows.  But it's so cool to step out on the porch and watch them go by in tight formation... up, down, all around.  Apparently just 18 inches from each other - talk about a close talker... er, flier.  

I guess if I can support the troops I can enjoy watching the Angels.   Right around 3:30 on a Thursday afternoon the noise can start to get to you... but just lift your eyes to the sky and you'll likely be taken in by the scene.   You have to admit that's some pretty crazy talent.
author: Rashmi N.

description: Used to think they were pretty cool..that is until I grew up and had to start waking up early for work wondering WHAT on EARTH was making that loud noise hovering over my roof for hours on end...KILLING my precious and I really do mean PRECIOUS sleep!
author: Petra S.

description:
This is really something I look forward to every year. For those of you who complain, dude, learn to deal.  It is a couple of days once a year.  Yeah, yeah, I know you hate the military and they are loud, blah blah blah.  

However, these are incredibly TALENTED and skilled pilots.  Maybe for once you can appreciate the artistry and ability that goes into an airshow.  My brother is a pilot (not a military one though).  Maybe seeing all of the education that he had to go through just to fly people around safely makes me appreciate how much work it really is.  

Come on and enjoy the show.  The Blue Angels are our country's absolutely BEST pilots.  We should be so thankful that we get a chance to witness not just the skill and artistry in their shows, but also the marvels of engineering that make it so a plane can move like that.  

So, chill out, relax, and enjoy a freaking great show on a nice sunny day.
author: Kate B.

description: Multi-billlion dollar killing machines.  Not appropriate for this fair and peaceful city.  Go away!
author: Eric H.

description:
GO AMERICA! !!!

Is what I would be saying if these bastards hadn't decided to start flying above a music festival. I mean, don't get me wrong, I love America as much as the next person. This country is awesome, it's a fantastic hodge-podge of people from all around the world, all here because of the amazing freedoms we are afforded daily.

Apparently one such freedom is to join the Air Force, fly a multi-million dollar military jet and get really good at performing fancy tricks and maneuvers for a crowd of over 100,000 cheering spectators, because that's what some people have certainly been doing. Those people are called the Blue Angels, and the Blue Angels are quite obviously not fans of bluegrass music festivals. 

I am, however, and since the Blue Angels decided that flying over one such festival was a good idea, I'm going to have to give them a 1. For shame America, for shame!
author: Adam M.

description:
Minus 1 star because W gets a boner for shit like this....but I gotta admit, I get a half chub for sure. The skill of these pilots combined with the brains it takes to create this awe-inspiring technology is amazing, political views aside. 
Seeing this show with the backdrop of SF, The Bay and the Golden Gate is spectacular. I'd never seen the Angels until I moved to SF and got quite the suprise when you heard them buzzing the City during their practice runs. This year didn't seem as loud- did something change in their routine? 
My fave BA moment was a few years ago when I was playing Presidio GC on the Thurday practice day and the buzzed the treetops as I played the 10th hole. Wow.
author: Matt H.

description:
AAAAAAAAMAZING!

LOVE the airshow! 

SPECTACULAR!
author: Judy K.

description:
One time my co-worker from Canada hid behind a desk because the sound from the Blue Angels were so roaring that he thought it was a terrorist attack. 

That was rich.
author: Jordan A.

description:
HEy slackers I feel like I should reiterate that the blue angels rule.  It s too bad that the red bull race was in Paris this year but thats how it goes.  Fleet week, not as cool as last year but how cool  anyway.  And for the haters 2007 has  once again given you an alternative.  Totally strictly hippy-fest in the park.  Then sunday you could go to the Decompression party for burning man if you were able to find your way back up her from the desert.

   Blue Angels,  Awwesome!  Sure I  will go to the indy coffee store before starbucks but I also like seeing my tax dollars well spent.  Tell me the last time you enjoyed watching a moment in congress.
  To agree with a fellow reviewee,  If you dont like it get out of the city for the weekend.  You can hop in your volvo,  get your hippy ass out to burning-man, do some payotee and see how many non starbucks you can get your caffeeeen high from thatt aren't 7-11.  And if that doesnt work it should be about 110.  You oughta see angels then.
author: Tony B.

description:
Mother fuckin' snakes on a plane these are incredible machines.  But after dating a pilot, I've had my fair share.  Now the only time I want to see an F/A-18 is from the pilot's seat.

Always a little place in my heart for the F16 Fighting Falcon though.
author: Vanessa Z.

description:
I didn't think anyone can dislike or even hate the Blue Angels but I guess to each his own.

The Blue Angels are awesome - we enjoyed the show and don't mind the noise.  My tax dollars have gone to plenty things that I don't care for so I'm glad at least this brings me and plenty others some entertainment once a year.
author: Gloria H.

description:
They are coming back in October !! get ready.   (and for the haters - remember that these pilots/planes are part of your country - the part that defends the freedoms you enjoy - yet obviously take for granted)

Blaze on . Blue Angels!!
author: scott P.

description:
I LIKE sleeping until noon on my off days. But I can't on fleet week as they zoom everywhere.

Although they do get one star because the caveperson in me likes looking up and going "ooooo, pretty."
author: Regina L.

description:
airplanes rule.  especially when they're going really fast, flying 18 inches apart from each other and making loud noises.  PSHWAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARRRR.  Just like that.  But a lot more repetitive and louder.

There is nothing like being on a rooftop party with cold beers and the Top Gun soundtrack blasting in the background watching these F/A-18's do really cool tricks and zoom over your head.  It really is a site and sound to behold.

Gets you all hopped up and giddy.  Or maybe it was the beer.  Or both.
author: Erika C.

description:
Whoever doesn't like the Blue Angels is a terrorist... or a communist.  or something anti American."

As far back as i can remember, i always loved going to marina green and watching them.  It is amazing that they have the precision, and skill to do what they do.  This is always on my to do list when they are in town, although usually i go during their practice survey flights.  And even if it means i have to get stuck in traffic for hours, and walk a mile to get close.

When they fly over my head, with that loud roar... I feel like a child again, and just want to start cheering.  Seriously, it almost brings tears to my eyes at how happy i feel when they fly.

And the noise.  Make it louder.  Sometimes, i just want them to fly over head, and get so loud that i go deaf.  And then i can say, it was all worth it.  Even though i really wouldn't like it.

To all those who complain about the noise... get over it.  The blue angels represent America.  The United States.  It does represent the military, and they are liaisons between the public and the government.  They do good, and bring joy to our lives.  Maybe your parents didn't bring you there when you were young.  But mine did.  And i am sure glad they did.

BLUE ANGELS ROCK!!!!!
author: Terence P.

description:
I awakened this morning to the lovely sounds of jets flying over my neighborhood at Mach 5 speeds. When the Angels are in town you needn't set your morning alarm.

I am still hoping and waiting for these mofo's to get technical with their shit and start maneuvering those babies through buildings on Montgomery Street.  I grow tired of seeing them fly under bridges. 

Come on Blue Angels......I challenge you. Make me go deaf by showing me something completely awesome.
author: James J.

description: Blue Angels - proving we can spend tax dollars to kill people in far away places more effectively than anyone else, while causing noise pollution and disrupting people's ability to work.
author: Mitra A.

description: Would give them 10 stars if I could. Look, I'm as progressive as anybody else in this city, so I recognize self-righteous bullish*t when I see it. And 99% of the negative reviews for the Angels on this site are just that. If you hate them that much, make plans to deal with it. It isn't a surprise, they are here every year. The planes are not armed, they aren't celebrating war, they are just plain badass. And though I despise how much $$ this country spends on defense, and am outraged over wars in the Middle East, I have zero problem with the best pilots in the world demonstrating how incredible these machines are. And yes, I get a little thrill knowing that the Navy is out there, ostensibly at least, to protect our shores. Get a grip, one-star posters, and let your hair down a little. Have some fun for once.
author: Justin H.

description: I love when the blue angels come to town!! they zoooom by my window!!!! This year is going to be great too... im so excited!
author: Samantha R.

description: One of the many best perks to live in The City. Go Blue and a safe and great performance to them tomorrow!
author: Shureluck H.

description: HOT Watch them over the great views of SF during Fleet Week . They will be here and gone before the blink of an eye and their loud sound will remain till they are back...goodluck getting a picture they are SUPER FAST. Love jets...this is the Jets to watch ...
author: Lillian O.

description: So our Government does not have funds to support our Veterans,seniors and youth but they found millions of $$$$ to reactivate the Blue Angels in 2014? San Francisco banned the Blue Angels for noise abatement and a near mid air crash, yet SF gets all the revenue from Blue Angels and Fleet week. Oakland and the Port of Oakland cash in on use of the North Field at Oakland Airport. The Blue Angels roar about 500 feet over the tops of residences in Alameda as they take off fully loaded with fuel. Alameda gets the peanut shells. Has the Navy brass and the FAA not considered the death toll and damage to homes should one of these fighter jets crash on take off? We have Moffett Field and Travis Air Force Base that could be easily used as their base. The saddest part is that Alameda residents are put through this fear and thundering noise, yet the Blue Angels did not come over the former Alameda Naval Air Station even once to satisfy the onlookers from all over the East Bay who had gathered on the base to watch the jets high above.
